dt: {bc}to enter by gradual steps or by stealth into the possessions or rights of another
{bc}to advance beyond the usual or proper limits

pt: {sc}trespass{/sc} {sc}encroach{/sc} {sc}infringe{/sc} {sc}invade{/sc} mean to make inroads upon the property, territory, or rights of another. {sc}trespass{/sc} implies an unwarranted or unlawful intrusion.
{sc}encroach{/sc} suggests gradual or stealthy entrance upon another's territory or usurpation of another's rights or possessions.

pt.t: the {it}encroaching{/it} settlers displacing the native peoples

pt: {sc}infringe{/sc} implies an encroachment clearly violating a right or prerogative.
{sc}invade{/sc} implies a hostile and injurious entry into the territory or sphere of another.

et: Middle English {it}encrochen{/it} to get, seize, from Anglo-French {it}encrocher{/it}, from {it}en-{/it} + {it}croc, croche{/it} hook {ma}{mat|crochet|}{/ma}
shortdef: to enter by gradual steps or by stealth into the possessions or rights of another
to advance beyond the usual or proper limits
